The rampant buying comes after months of persistent selling by foreign portfolio managers, including a net withdrawal of about $4 billion from Indian equities in February. On Tuesday, Indian equities’ winning streak reached seven days. All the buying has erased the losses for the calendar year so far, and comes after over $1 trillion was erased from the value of the equity market since its September peak. The trough reflected weak corporate earnings and foreign capital outflows. Despite the recovery, analysts warn the next set of Trump tariffs, set to kick in on April 2, could impact the rupee. “If tariffs come to have a substantial economic impact,” ANZ’s Nim said, “I think the most natural course of action should be to let the rupee weaken, as that can absorb a part of that shock.” India was on a list of countries of “particular interest” to the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative when it requested public comments on trade tariffs. “We estimate India would potentially lose about $6 billion (0.16% of GDP) in exports to the US at 10% broad tariffs, with this rising to about $31 billion at 25% tariffs,” brokerage Emkay Global said in a note on Tuesday. ANZ’s Nim said India’s central bank has allowed the rupee to considerably appreciate, potentially creating “headroom” for depreciation. “If tariffs hit and [the currency] depreciates to 87.5, it is still familiar territory,” he said. “But if it goes beyond 88 or 89, then imported inflation becomes something to worry about. … The RBI rule of thumb is a 5% depreciation (in the rupee) leads to a 35 basis point bump in inflation.”

title: China’s DeepSeek updates V3 model in challenge to OpenAI’s GPT-4.5
description: DeepSeek, symbolic of Chinese AI ingenuity, has helped the Hang Seng Tech Index surge around 25% since the start of 2025. © Reuters Version improves on predecessor and outperforms U.S. rival in some tasks CISSY ZHOU March 26, 2025 11:38 JST HONG KONG — Chinese AI startup DeepSeek quietly released an update to its V3 large language model on Tuesday evening, significantly enhancing its reasoning capabilities and further escalating competition with U.S. rival OpenAI. Dubbed DeepSeek-V3-0324, the updated model has improved significantly over its predecessor, especially in advanced math and coding, according to the company’s post on Hugging Face, a U.S. open-source AI community. Benchmark tests show DeepSeek’s latest model outperforms GPT-4.5 in coding and mathematical reasoning, while GPT-4.5 remains the strongest overall in knowledge-based tasks. The new V3 model further optimizes the writing level of Chinese writing tasks based on its R1 model, with a particular focus on improving the content quality of medium-to-long-form text creation, according to DeepSeek. “From a purely technical perspective, there isn’t a major breakthrough in DeepSeek’s update compared to its previous versions, and I think all models will continue to update rapidly, but the impact won’t be as significant as the leap from zero to one,” said Eugene Lee, a Hong Kong-based AI engineer. “However, as an open-source model, DeepSeek’s updated capabilities matching GPT-4.5 are relatively rare,” he said. After taking the tech world by storm in January with its cheap-to-train but robust AI model, DeepSeek has become the poster child for Chinese AI ingenuity. The startup’s meteoric rise has rekindled optimism about Chinese innovation and bolstered Beijing’s commitment to supporting its tech players. DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng and Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma were among the Chinese tech entrepreneurs who attended a high-profile gathering with Chinese President Xi Jinping last month, further fueling a tech market rally around China’s AI advancement. The Hang Seng Tech Index has surged around 25% since the start of the year.

title: South Korea’s ‘worst-ever’ wildfires kill at least 18
description: A firefighter works to extinguish flames at a house that has been engulfed by a wildfire in Uiseong, South Korea, on March 25.  © AP Acting president says nation is mobilizing all available resources to minimize casualties STEVEN BOROWIEC March 26, 2025 11:31 JST SEOUL — Strong winds are driving wildfires in southeastern South Korea, fueling what the country’s acting president is calling the most damaging blazes in the country’s history. Han Duck-soo said Wednesday that 18 people, including four firefighters, have died in the fires and 23,000 people were evacuated from their homes. He added that 244 wildfires have occurred in South Korea this year, 2.4 times more than by the same time last year. Also, 17,000 hectares of woodland and 209 locations, such as homes and factories, have been destroyed. To combat the fires, Han said 4,652 personnel have been activated, as well as 128 helicopters, with additional support from the U.S. military stationed in South Korea. “We are fighting the worst wildfires in history using all the manpower and equipment that we can mobilize but the situation is dire,” Han said, according to a release from his office. Han expressed thanks to all emergency personnel and government workers who are engaged in battling and dealing with the fallout from the blazes. “The whole nation is watching as you work to protect your hometowns, your families and your neighbors,” he said. Wildfires tend to occur in the spring in South Korea, a time of strong winds and dry weather conditions. Officials have not pinpointed a cause of this year’s exceptionally severe blazes, but Han said Wednesday that fires lit by locals to incinerate waste are the main cause of wildfires. This week’s weather forecast is for continued dry conditions and only a low chance of rain. The disaster is taking place at a time of political chaos in South Korea, created by President Yoon Suk Yeol’s botched attempt at instituting emergency martial law in early December. Yoon is currently awaiting a Constitutional Court verdict that will either formally remove or return him to office. He was impeached in December and a verdict in his case has been hotly anticipated for weeks, since the court held its final hearing in his case in late February. Han resumed duties as acting president on Monday when the same court that will rule on Yoon’s fate decided to reject his impeachment and restore him to office. Opposition lawmakers voted to impeach Han in December, after he was named acting leader following Yoon’s impeachment.

title: Trump administration hits China with slew of tech export controls
description: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration has added more than 50 Chinese companies to an export control list. © Reuters Move targets advanced computing and hypersonic weapon capabilities KENJI KAWASE March 26, 2025 11:18 JST HONG KONG — U.S. President Donald Trump’s administration has significantly expanded the trade blacklist it inherited from the previous Joe Biden team, aiming to further constrict China’s capabilities to develop artificial intelligence and advanced computing, as well as direct military technologies like hypersonic missiles. The Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) of the U.S. Commerce Department has added 80 organizations to the Entity List for actions “contrary to U.S. national security and foreign policy.” The additions to the blacklist include entities from the United Arab Emirates, South Africa, Iran and even Taiwan, but most are either Chinese or linked to China. BIS, in an announcement released Tuesday in Washington, identified a key objective of preventing the Chinese Communist Party from gaining the ability to “acquire and develop high-performance and exascale computing capabilities, as well as quantum technologies, for military applications.” Exascale computing is the latest supercomputer technology enabling further development of AI. It describes computing at speeds of at least 1 exaflop, or 1 quintillion floating-point calculations per second. Another goal was to “impede China’s development of its hypersonic weapons program,” essentially, weapons that travel five times the speed of sound or faster and boast enhanced maneuverability to evade defenses. Military vehicles carrying DF-17 hypersonic missiles drive past Beijing’s Tiananmen Square during a National Day parade in October 2019.   © Reuters “American technology should never be used against the American people,” Jeffrey I. Kessler, undersecretary for industry and security at the Commerce Department, said in the statement. He stressed that the Trump administration is “sending a clear, resounding message” to safeguard national security “by preventing U.S. technologies and goods from being misused for high-performance computing, hypersonic missiles, military aircraft training, and UAVs that threaten our national security.” The Commerce Department also listed the Test Flying Academy of South Africa (TFASA) to prevent the use of “U.S. items to train Chinese military forces.” Apart from China, the expanded list is also intended to “disrupt Iran’s procurement of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and related defense items.” Kessler added that the Entity List is “one of many powerful tools at our disposal to identify and cut off foreign adversaries seeking to exploit American technology for malign purposes.” China had not responded to the U.S. announcement as of publication time.

title: Trump’s World Liberty Financial crypto venture to launch stablecoin
description: Then-former President Donald Trump speaks at the Bitcoin 2024 Conference in July 2024, in Nashville, Tennessee. © AP Venture raises $550m from selling separate digital token March 26, 2025 10:27 JST LONDON (Reuters) — Donald Trump’s World Liberty Financial crypto venture will launch a dollar-pegged stablecoin, it said in a statement on Tuesday, after raising more than half a billion dollars from selling a separate digital token. The stablecoin, called USD1, will be fully backed by U.S. Treasuries, dollars and other cash equivalents and is designed to keep a value of $1, World Liberty said in the statement. Dollar-pegged stablecoins such as Tether and USDC have ballooned in recent years and now act as a key cog in the multi-trillion dollar crypto trading industry, helping move funds between different cryptocurrencies or into regular cash. Stablecoins in circulation currently total over $237 billion, according to data provider CoinGecko. The tokens have become lucrative for their issuers in recent years as interest rates spiked. Tether, the issuer of the world’s biggest stablecoin, made over $13 billion in profits last year. Zach Witkoff, World Liberty’s co-founder, said “sovereign investors and major institutions” would be able to integrate USD1 “into their strategies for seamless, secure cross-border transactions.” USD1 will be “fully backed by a reserve portfolio audited regularly by a third-party accounting firm,” World Liberty said, without giving details of the accounting firm, or the date of its launch. Founded two months before his victory in the U.S. presidential election, World Liberty’s creation was announced by Trump, his three sons and the wealthy real estate businessman Steve Witkoff, who is the father of Zach and now Trump’s Middle East envoy. Trump, who campaigned on promises to be a “crypto president,” has pledged to overhaul U.S. rules on crypto and reverse a crackdown on the sector that took place under former President Joe Biden. His crypto business interests, which include a so-called meme coin launched in January, have drawn criticism from government ethics experts and political opponents over potential conflicts of interest. The World Liberty venture, which aims to allow people to access financial services without intermediaries like banks, said last week it has raised $550 million selling a crypto coin known as $WLFI. Kevin Lehtiniitty, CEO of New York payments infrastructure firm Borderless.xyz said USD1 would face stiff competition from incumbents such as Tether and U.S. firm Circle, the issuer of USDC. “While launching a stablecoin is easy, building an ecosystem that adopts it is a far harder task,” he said. “Is the President competing with other American businesses or will they find ways to partner?” USD1’s reserves will be held in custody by California-based BitGo, World Liberty said. BitGo’s prime brokerage service will support USD1 by “providing institutional clients with access to deep liquidity and trading,” it added. USD1 will be launched on the Ethereum and Binance Smart Chain blockchains – digital ledgers that underpin the movement of crypto coins. World Liberty plans to launch USD1 on other blockchains in the future, it added. Binance, the world’s biggest crypto exchange, launched its so-called Smart Chain in 2020. It is the world’s fourth-largest blockchain by the value of assets held on it, according to CoinGecko. Binance’s founder and former CEO Changpeng Zhao was last year sentenced to four months in a U.S. prison, after pleading guilty to violating U.S. laws against money laundering. Binance paid a $4.3 billion fine after U.S. prosecutors said it had welcomed criminals and failed to report over 100,000 suspicious transactions with designated terrorist groups. A spokesperson for Binance did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment about how the partnership came about.

title: Indonesia’s Danantara targets $8bn in dividends from state-owned companies
description: Pandu Patria Sjahrir, chief investment officer of Danantara, told Nikkei Asia that one of the priorities of Indonesia's new sovereign wealth fund is to professionalize the country's state-owned enterprises. (Photo by Dimas Ardian) CIO says sovereign wealth fund needs to 'explain our intentions' to skeptical investors ISMI DAMAYANTI March 26, 2025 10:16 JST JAKARTA — Indonesia’s four-week-old sovereign wealth fund will seek to earn $8 billion a year — a 60% increase on the current level — in dividends from state-owned enterprises (SOEs), according to its chief investment officer. As of this week, the fund, Daya Anagata Nusantara, or Danantara, oversees 47 SOEs with assets of some $900 billion that gave the government a total of $5.1 billion in dividends in 2024. “Every year, we [will aim to] receive dividends of at least $8 billion,” Pandu Patria Sjahrir told Nikkei Asia in an interview when asked about the fund’s target. He added, without giving specifics, that the longer-term goal would be to generate even greater returns. He also did not give details about when the extra dividend revenue would be generated or how – except through making “high-return” investments and professionalizing the SOEs, partly by making them less political.  Sjahrir explained that Danantara will function as a super holding company, overseeing investment strategies for SOEs. “Think of us as a financier, we’re investors who invest in projects and can collaborate with operational partners,” he said. Dividends from SOEs would be reinvested while ensuring returns from these initiatives are allocated to finance government programs. “I imagine that in five years, we could have $40 billion to invest in the market,” he predicted. The optimism contrasts with the current market uncertainty about Danantara and Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto’s broader economic agenda. Indonesia’s benchmark equity index is down 20% since Prabowo was inaugurated five months ago, with SOEs including Bank Mandiri and Bank Rakyat Indonesia among the biggest losers. The rupiah, meanwhile, has been one of the worst performing emerging market currencies this year, falling more than 3%. On Tuesday it hit its lowest level against the dollar since June 1998 during the Asian financial crisis. Sjahrir responded to this by saying that one of his primary roles is to engage with investors to build confidence and clarity about the fund’s direction. “After we explain Danantara to investors, they get excited. This is such a big change [that] disrupts the status quo, which leads to people thinking that there’s high uncertainty. So our job is to explain our intentions,” he said. According to Sjahrir, Danantara will follow a prudent risk management approach. “We have to make money … after that, we also want to bring in partners that add value, such as technology and knowledge — both would be even better,” he said, adding that investments will average around $500 million and focus on Indonesia. “We’re a very large country, and we will be investing inward, focusing on growing our own economy.” “This differs from INA, which is more likely to go with smaller projects with deal sizes from $50 million to $300 million,” he said, referring to Indonesia’s other sovereign wealth fund, the Indonesia Investment Authority, which was created in 2020. Sjahrir also stressed that Danantara will remain separate from INA and allow private investors to co-invest alongside it. “This is important because we want the private sector to invest with us.” Danantara is said to be focusing on sectors aligned with government priorities to boost domestic investment, including downstream industries, energy security, food security and digital infrastructure. On Monday it announced 18 people who would join its management, supervisory board and steering committee, including former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, American billionaire Ray Dalio, Columbia University economist Jeffrey Sachs and a former CEO of nickel miner Vale Indonesia, Febriany Eddy. American billionaire hedge fund owner Ray Dalio, left, former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, center, and U.S. economist Jeffrey Sachs are among the high-profile global figures who have been appointed to roles at Danantara. (Photos by Reuters and Getty Images) Prabowo last week inaugurated the Precious Metal Refinery, owned by Freeport Indonesia, a subsidiary of state-owned mining holding company Mind ID, which is now under Danantara’s management. Sjahrir said that similar projects would be among Danantara’s future investment priorities. “Those types of projects bring significant value to the country, economic benefits, technological advancements, and knowledge transfer, and we should aim to establish more,” he said. “Additionally, data centers are also very interesting … especially when data sovereignty comes into play, meaning that most of the data must remain within the country.” One of Danantara’s key objectives, Sjahrir explained, is to professionalize the SOEs. “That’s probably the most important, because [SOEs] can behave like a full economic actor, not a state actor,” he said.  This would involve making them less political. “That’s always been the key issue with state owned enterprises is that the mix of politics and the business are too strongly intertwined,” Sjahrir said. “We’re hoping with Danantara, we can separate and minimize the political issue and focus more on the corporate.” Additionally, Danantara is intending to redirect SOE dividends from the state budget into an investment fund, where they can be managed for long-term economic growth and value creation, rather than being immediately spent by the government. “This way, the money [goes] for working capital of the state.” Sjahrir emphasized that these changes will be a major driver in shifting Indonesia from a consumption-based economy to an investment-driven economy. Currently, household consumption accounts for 53.7% of Indonesia’s gross domestic product, followed by investment and trade. The government aims to double investment growth from 5% to 10%, in order to achieve annual economic growth of 8%. However, Danantara has myriad challenges, with underperforming SOEs burdened by significant liabilities, including state-owned construction companies  and PLN, the national electricity utility. “[For SOEs] that are not performing, we should ask why. Should they be consolidated so they get bigger and then they can have economies of scale?” For companies in severe financial distress, Danantara’s approach will be clear-cut, they will either be liquidated or sold. “If [an SOE is] already at some scale, then we scale it up or we should find strategic investors,” he said. Mohammad Faisal, executive director at the Center of Reform on Economics (CORE), said expecting significantly higher dividends from SOEs can only be realistic as a medium- to long-term strategy. “In the short term, Danantara should focus on improving SOE governance, particularly in state-owned construction companies,” he said. Faisal warned that pushing for higher dividends too quickly would be “very challenging” and could place a burden on currently profitable SOEs such as state-owned banks, telecom provider Telkom, and Pertamina, the main government oil and gas company. “The government has focused heavily on promoting the long-term benefits, but in the short term, many risks may be overlooked,” he said.

title: Trump team scrambles to handle fallout from Signal chat blunder
description: CIA Director John Ratcliffe, right, and Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard testify before a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing in Washington on March 25. © Reuters Intel officials say no classified info shared in group discussion March 26, 2025 09:04 JST WASHINGTON (Reuters) — The Trump administration sought on Tuesday to contain the fallout after a magazine journalist disclosed he had been inadvertently included in a secret group discussion of highly sensitive war plans, while Democrats called on top officials to resign over the security incident. Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard and CIA Director John Ratcliffe — both of whom were in the chat — testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee that no classified material was shared in the group chat on Signal, an encrypted commercial messaging app. But Democratic senators voiced skepticism, noting that the journalist, Atlantic Editor-in-Chief Jeffrey Goldberg, reported that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth posted operational details about pending strikes against Yemen’s Iran-aligned Houthis, “including information about targets, weapons the U.S. would be deploying, and attack sequencing.” Committee members said they planned — and Gabbard and Ratcliffe agreed to — an audit of the exchange. The Senate’s Republican majority leader, John Thune, said on Tuesday he expected the Senate Armed Services Committee to look in to Trump administration officials’ use of Signal. “It’s hard for me to believe that targets and timing and weapons would not have been classified,” Sen. Angus King, a Maine independent who caucuses with Democrats, said at the contentious hearing, which featured several sharp exchanges. Gabbard repeatedly referred questions about the exchange to Hegseth and the Department of Defense. She and Ratcliffe will face more lawmakers on Wednesday when the House of Representatives will hold its annual “Worldwide Threats” hearing. Democrats said they planned to discuss the Signal chat. The revelation on Monday drew outrage and disbelief among national security experts and prompted Democrats — and some of President Donald Trump’s fellow Republicans — to call for an investigation of what they called a major security breach. “I am of the view that there ought to be resignations, starting with the national security adviser and the secretary of defense,” Democratic Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon said at the hearing. But Trump voiced support for his national security team when questioned about the incident at a White House event on Tuesday with Michael Waltz, his national security adviser who mistakenly added Goldberg to the Signal discussion. Trump said the administration would look into the use of Signal. He said that he did not think Waltz should apologize but that he did not think Waltz and the team would be using Signal again soon. Sen. Jon Ossoff of Georgia appeared to grow frustrated after Ratcliffe answered “I don’t recall” to a series of questions about the content of the Signal chat. “Director Ratcliffe, surely you prepared for this hearing today,” Ossoff said. “You are part of a group of principals, senior echelons of the U.S. government, and now a widely publicized breach of sensitive information.” Some Republicans also wanted to know more. Sen. Todd Young said he would inquire during a closed hearing later on Tuesday. “It appears to me there are some unanswered questions,” the Indiana Republican said. A former U.S. official told Reuters that operational details for military actions are typically classified and known to only a few people at the Pentagon and such top secret information is usually kept on computers that use a separate network. National Security Council spokesperson Brian Hughes said on Monday that the chat group appeared to be authentic. Sensitive information is not supposed to be shared on commercial mobile phone apps. Additionally, Signal’s ability to erase conversations would violate laws governing the retention of government records. “This is one more example of the kind of sloppy, careless, incompetent behavior, particularly toward classified information … of this administration,” the committee’s Democratic vice chairman, Mark Warner of Virginia, said. Accounts appearing to represent Vice President JD Vance, Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Hegseth, Ratcliffe, Gabbard, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, White House chief of staff Susie Wiles, and senior National Security Council officials were assembled in the chat group, Goldberg wrote on Monday. Gabbard acknowledged that she had been abroad during the chat, although she declined to say whether she was using a private phone. The White House sought to play down the incident. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt accused Goldberg of sensationalizing the story in a post on X. Also on X, White House communications director Steven Cheung dismissed as “faux outrage” the concern over the inclusion of a journalist in a war-planning chat. Hegseth told reporters on Monday that no one had texted war plans. Goldberg, appearing on CNN on Monday, called those comments “a lie.” It remained unclear why the officials chose to chat via Signal rather than the secure government channels typically used for sensitive discussions. Signal has a “stellar reputation and is widely used and trusted in the security community,” said Rocky Cole, whose cybersecurity firm iVerify helps protect smartphone users from hackers. “The risk of discussing highly sensitive national security information on Signal isn’t so much that Signal itself is insecure,” Cole added. “It’s the fact that nation-states threat actors have a demonstrated ability to remotely compromise the entire mobile phone itself. If the phone itself isn’t secure, all the Signal messages on that device can be read.” Republican Representative Don Bacon, a retired Air Force general who sits on the House Armed Services Committee, told reporters that Hegseth needed to take responsibility for the apparent breach, which he said put lives at risk. Asked about the claim that no classified details were shared, Bacon responded, “They ought to just be honest and own up to it.”

title: Sake segues into the 21st century
description: Bottles of sake line the wall behind the counter of a bar in Niigata prefecture, where small, independent sake breweries abound. (Photo by Kaori Shoji) Women and foreign drinkers are lapping up Japan's traditional 'old man's' drink KAORI SHOJI March 26, 2025 08:00 JST Sake, Japan’s traditional brewed alcohol drink, has been steadily trending overseas for some time. Sure, the painstakingly crafted rice wine gained a boost last year when the knowledge and skills required for traditional sake-making were recognized by UNESCO as an intangible world heritage asset. But even without the distinction, Japan had seen sake exports climbing steadily. In 2024, 31,000 kiloliters of sake were transported overseas, up by more than 100% from the previous year. That generated revenue of more than 43 billion yen ($287.9 million at current exchange rates), up 105.8%. Companies like Takara Holdings, an acclaimed sake maker with offshore offices the world over, have seized the opportunity to expand their North American operations and work with European food and beverage companies. The Japanese have long known that sake is their cuisine’s most reliable friend, having the capacity to perk up even the humblest of foodstuffs (dried squid and sesame seeds, anyone?). Now it seems the rest of the world is catching on. Having an authentic sake-plus-Japanese food experience is one of the top five reasons why inbound tourists head to Japan. Tokyo bars are crowded with foreign travelers staring at the sake descriptions on translated-to-English menus. For the Japanese however, the strokes on the canvas are less bold. According to a survey conducted by a sake maker in Yamagata prefecture, young people in their 20s and 30s say that sake is not their drink, preferring fizzy cocktails. But sake has found a wider fan base among Japanese women. Compared with 2017, the number of women who prefer sake has doubled, according to PR Times, a Japanese business information provider. These women are in their mid-30s or older, and are discerning drinkers who have a favorite sake region and kura (independent sake brewing house) making handmade brews. They frequent small, tucked-away sake bars and are knowledgeable about which drinks to pair with foods. Sake on tap at a standing bar: Insert a coin into the corresponding sake of choice and you will get one pour (approximately three sips). (Photos by Kaori Shoji) A friend who was once a French wine enthusiast now says: “The pandemic, low yen [exchange] rate and soaring energy costs have messed up the imported wine market [in Japan]. These days, I’m for sake. It fills me with a sense of well-being without the additional guilt and sticker shock.” She has a point. The best sake is brewed from a sustainable ecological process that uses just three ingredients: water, rice and a rice mold known as koji . Brewed with rice grains and water, the koji releases sugars that turn the liquid into sake. The process requires a pristine water supply, which in turn calls for a pure, industry-free environment. Most independent brewing houses are family businesses tucked away in mountainous rural areas. The brewers, known as tojis , are sake artisans, and the profession is hereditary. Some tojis can trace their family lineage back to the 17th century, and their brewing methods are kept under lock and key. “All this history is thrilling,” says my friend. “I used to avoid sake because it seemed like an old man’s drink. But it’s time to share in the joys.” She now uses sake-based cosmetics and swears that her sake moisturizer has made her skin more supple. Top: A  toji (master brewer) spreads steamed rice on a table in a hot room where the rice is treated with a mold called koji  in preparation for brewing sake. (Getty Images) Bottom: Sake-based face masks and hand cream. (Photos by Kaori Shoji) It is certainly true that tojis are known for their wrinkle-free hands — the reward for years of dedicated toil. In Niigata, a prefecture famed for its large number of independent brewing houses and the highest sake consumption rate in Japan, blemish-free skin is common. Another friend, who is a Niigata native, says his grandmother used sake on everything from bruises to depression. “Sake is the cure for 100 maladies,” he says. This friend is 51 but looks 20 years younger. But even the ancient, mythical world of sake is facing upheaval. Responding to the huge spike in offshore demand, major brewing companies have made the shift to digital production: Instead of relying on tojis’ experienced hands and sensibilities, computers control and supervise the brewing process. Other companies seem to be prioritizing foreign consumers over Japanese. In 2023 the luxury sake brand Dassai made headlines by opening a brewery in New York state’s Hudson River Valley. When the company’s president moved there too, sake purists posted their disappointment on social media. “Sake is uniquely Japanese and belongs right here in Japan,” said one disappointed traditionalist. My father, who hailed from Japan’s northeast, was a big sake drinker. During winter Sundays, he started the afternoon with an atsukan (hot sake). It was my job to heat it in a ceramic carafe, in water that was heated to 85 C for 2.5 minutes. Ideally, the atsukan should be hitohada (skin temperature), but in our icy kitchen my hands often felt too cold to offer a reference point. Dassai Blue 23, a high-end sake brewed in New York state’s Hudson River Valley, was served at the Academy Awards after-party in Los Angeles in February.    © Getty Images When finished, the atsukan would be carried by my mother to my father, waiting at the table. He would take a tiny ochoko sake cup into his hand, and she would pour the drink for him. The first sip, he said, was the most important — it indicated whether the sake was heated properly. As a matter of course, I grew up resenting sake because of this rigmarole. When I learned that there was an electric sake heater on sale at a nearby appliance store I asked my father to get one, but he refused. “The atsukan wouldn’t taste the same in an electric heater,” he said. “In a few more years you’ll understand the difference.” Now I spend winter weekends with my own heated sake, which I make in a ceramic carafe. Much as I hate to admit it, I do understand the difference. My family and friends say that I could get a job anytime in a sake bar. There are some things that humans do better than machines, and the atsukan ritual is one of them. Kaori Shoji is a contributing writer.

title: Japan’s growing foreign workforce offers succession lifeline
description: Yutaka Ofuku, left, who heads a machine parts maker in Osaka, oversees the work of his chosen successor, Vietnamese factory manager Bui Quoc Viet. (Photo by Arisa Moriyama) Immigrants may make up 10% of population by 2040s, forecast shows EUGENE LANG March 26, 2025 07:11 JST TOKYO — The owner of a machine parts maker in Osaka faced the prospect of the end of his seven-decade-old company. The small local manufacturer has big customers, including tractor maker Kubota, giving it solid earnings. But 68-year-old Yutaka Ofuku had no successor lined up, nor could he find a buyer he could trust. He was saved from this predicament by a Vietnamese employee: factory manager Bui Quoc Viet, who had joined the company 11 years earlier. The 38-year-old Bui had intended to eventually return to his home country and start his own business. He said he decided to succeed Ofuku instead “after seeing how troubled the president was.” “We won’t have to cause problems for our customers,” a relieved Ofuku said. Ofuku’s plight shows how important foreign talent has become even to the top ranks of Japanese companies as the country’s population ages. A Teikoku Databank survey found that 52% of businesses do not have a successor or have yet to decide on one. Even with the weak yen making Japan less attractive for employment, the country had a record 2.3 million foreign workers at the end of October. The Japan Research Institute has estimated that foreigners could make up more than 10% of the population as soon as the 2040s. The share could grow as high as 20% to 30% in Tokyo and Osaka, as immigrant populations worldwide tend to be concentrated in cities. Without foreign workers, a future is possible where damaged roads and bridges are left unrepaired and stores cannot be stocked daily. The Japan International Cooperation Agency predicts that 6.88 million foreign workers, triple the current number, will be needed in 2040. Money Forward, a provider of cloud-based accounting software, is ahead of the curve, with around 30% of its engineers in Japan hailing from outside the country. Although English is the official language in the engineering department, the company began providing introductory Japanese lessons in 2025 to help employees struggling to communicate at work or in their daily lives. Japanese employees, meanwhile, learn to speak a simpler version of Japanese that avoids complicated expressions, providing a compromise that helps build relationships. In Germany, where 18% of the population is foreign-born, the far-right Alternative for Germany party placed second in February’s general election on a platform opposed to mass immigration. But Japan, with its shrinking labor pool, is in a different position, argued Yu Korekawa of the National Institute of Population and Social Security Research. “There won’t be competition with foreigners for jobs,” Korekawa said. Rather, the priority will be working together with foreigners to ensure that society can continue on. While more foreigners are choosing Japan, the country faces competition from other work destinations. Last summer, a technical intern trainee from the Philippines who was working in Japan moved to Canada. “We are seeing an increasing number of people moving to countries with higher wages after acquiring skills here,” said the head of a human resources company. “Japan is becoming a steppingstone.”

title: Bank of Japan stays on sidelines as 10-year yield climbs toward 2%
description: The Bank of Japan has so far avoided stepping in to curb rising long-term government bond yields. (Photo by Akira Kodaka) Market watchers see room for further rise toward Tokyo's assumed debt-service rate Nikkei staff writers March 26, 2025 07:00 JST TOKYO — The Bank of Japan is taking a wait-and-see approach as yields on long-term Japanese government bonds rise, spurring commercial banks to follow suit while fueling concern in the Finance Ministry over an increase in debt-servicing costs. The BOJ opted against bond-buying operations as yields climbed after it raised interest rates at its January policy board meeting . Yields have risen further since, reaching a 16-year high of 1.57% for the 10-year JGBs this month, as investors steer clear of buying bonds . “The ceiling for rate hikes is a long way off,” said an executive at a major bank. “We can’t buy when we know that the policy rate will rise.” Market watchers are also mindful that long-term yields remain well below the Japanese government’s assumed interest rate for debt servicing costs, which was set at 2% in the fiscal 2025 draft budget. Though a BOJ insider said the central bank does not make policy decisions with that rate in mind, some investors see it essentially serving as an upper bound. Yields could rise faster than the Finance Ministry expects. Calculations published by the ministry in January used an assumed interest rate of 2.2% for fiscal 2026, working out to 12 trillion yen ($80 billion) in interest payments. But some in the ministry have begun to say that 3% would not be out of the question if current trends continue, which could affect the rest of the budget drafting process and risk a further deterioration in government finances. Japan’s ratio of government debt to gross domestic product exceeded 250% between 2020 and 2024, according to the Finance Ministry — the highest among the Group of Seven economies. A country’s finances worsen when the average nominal interest rate on outstanding government debt surpasses the nominal economic growth rate, as was largely the case for Japan in the two decades through fiscal 2010. It could face continued challenges given that interest rates are trending up. Overseas ratings agencies are paying closer attention to the risk of Japan’s fiscal position deteriorating or yields rising sharply. JGBs look unlikely to face a downgrade anytime soon. But if that did happen, fundraising would become more costly for Japanese banks and other businesses, with serious knock-on effects for economic activity. The rise in long-term yields is hitting regional banks, whose unrealized losses on domestic bonds totaled 1.96 trillion yen at the end of 2024, up about 520 billion yen from three months earlier. These banks are expected to buy new bonds when the next fiscal year begins in April, but may face the risk of more paper losses depending on how yields move. To reduce its risk of future losses, Fukuoka Financial Group shortened the average duration on its yen-denominated bond holdings to 2.86 years, from 3.59 years a year earlier. Other financial institutions are increasingly holding government bonds to maturity, meaning their book value does not need to be updated as their market valuation changes. Banks’ “skill at managing [bond] duration will be tested,” Tetsuya Akino, chairman of the Regional Banks Association of Japan, said in a news conference this month. BOJ Gov. Kazuo Ueda in February told parliament that the central bank would “flexibly increase government-bond-buying operations in extraordinary circumstances, such as a drastic increase in long-term yields.” The bank uses fixed-rate bond-buying operations as an emergency tool, and every rise in long-term yields brings renewed speculation that they could be brought back into play. But for the most part, BOJ officials have stayed silent out of concern that any comments could signal a return of the bank’s yield curve control policy, which sought to keep JGB yields within a specific range.

title: TSMC’s $165bn U.S. expansion push: ‘Inevitable’ but risky
description: Pressure from the U.S. government and clients is pulling TSMC to expand more and more in America. (Illustration by Yoshiko Kawano) Pressure on Taiwan mounts amid Washington's concerns over China's aggression CHENG TING-FANG and LAULY LI March 26, 2025 06:00 JST TAIPEI — When TSMC Chairman and CEO C.C. Wei stood next to U.S. President Donald Trump early this month and announced the world’s biggest chipmaker would be investing an additional $100 billion to build five more advanced chip facilities and an R&D center on American soil, many back home in Taiwan were worried about what it would mean economically and politically for the island. Taiwan has long taken a measure of comfort in its “Silicon shield,” the idea that its chip economy — the second largest in the world — makes it too important for the U.S. not to defend it should China ever invade. But the U.S. is now home to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.’s first cutting-edge plant overseas, which went into production in Arizona late last year, with some 3,000 employees on site. The chip titan is now busy installing clean room facilities at a second, more advanced plant in the state that will start pilot production by next year. And — Nikkei Asia can report for the first time — construction on a third Arizona plant is slated to begin this year. TSMC Chairman and CEO C.C. Wei, center, announces the chipmaker’s $100 billion additional investment in the U.S. at the White House on March 3.   © Reuters Labor shortages, ballooning material costs and cultural challenges mean it took nearly fives years to complete its first U.S. plant, but TSMC now expects the additional factories to be built closer to its usual “Taiwan speed” of roughly two years, sources told Nikkei Asia. “After a painful learning curve, we have finally connected most of the dots and know which local construction contractors we can work with in building new plants,” a chip executive with direct knowledge of the matter said. TSMC told Nikkei Asia that it still plans to start operations at the second Arizona plant, for 3-nanometer chips, by 2028, and the third one, for 2-nm and better chips, before the end of the decade. But the accelerated pace of construction, on top of the company’s massive new investment plan, is potentially worrying for anyone fearful of Taiwan losing the crown jewel of its most important industry. TSMC declined to comment on whether it is aiming to accelerate its expansion in the U.S. to a “Taiwan speed.” Back home in Taiwan, TSMC engineers and suppliers are arguably even busier, working at a feverish pace to increase production at several cutting-edge 2-nm plants that are scheduled to begin production this year in Hsinchu and Kaohsiung. TSMC told Nikkei Asia that it is continuing to expand its 3-nm plant in Tainan. Next-generation A14 and A10 chips, which will mark the start of the so-called angstrom era, are under development at a “mother plant” near the company’s headquarters in Hsinchu. The company is also building advanced chip packaging facilities in Tainan, Chiayi and Miaoli to meet soaring demand from chip developers such as Nvidia, Amazon and Google in response to the boom in artificial intelligence. But this flurry of activity cannot disguise the fact TSMC and Taiwan more broadly are facing unprecedented levels of pressure from the U.S. and China. Over the past five years, as Washington has pressed for ever more onshoring of vital chip production, TSMC’s planned investment in the U.S. has ballooned from an initial $12 billion to $40 billion by 2022, then to $65 billion, in hopes of securing subsidies under the CHIPS Act, and finally to $165 billion — more than 10 times its original commitment and its largest overseas investment ever.   Relations between Beijing and Taipei, meanwhile, have continued to deteriorate. The Chinese Communist Party-led China views democratic, self-governed Taiwan — which it has never ruled — as part of its territory and has not ruled out taking over the island by force. China has intensified its pressure through frequent live-fired military drills around the island in the past few years, while Taiwan’s newly elected President Lai Ching-te recently described China as a “ foreign hostile force ,” which Beijing reacted to by staging another military drill. Taiwan’s President Lai Ching-te visits the Songshan airbase in Taipei on March 21. Lai drew Beijing’s ire when he described China as a “hostile foreign force.”   © Reuters Multiple chip industry executives and market experts told Nikkei Asia that TSMC’s stepped-up investment in the U.S. stems mainly from fears among customers and in Washington that growing Chinese aggression could disrupt global chip supplies. Raymond Greene, director of the American Institute in Taiwan, the U.S.’s de facto embassy, warned that if a catastrophic military conflict were to break out in the Taiwan Strait, an estimated 10% of global GDP could be affected, exceeding the impact of World War II. The Semiconductor Industry Association estimates disruptions at Taiwan’s contract chipmakers could cost electronic device makers $500 billion, while Rhodium Group predicts more than $2 trillion in economic activity would be at risk in such a conflict. TSMC’s Wei said at a private gathering at the National Taiwan University that if there were no TSMC, “The world’s economy would basically stall.” “There could be half of new cars that could not be shipped, with TSMC building some 50% of chips for car brakes. … There could be no new [generations] of smartphones, no [new] washing machines on sale if there were no TSMC,” he told the gathering. While Washington has been pressing TSMC to diversify production, American clients are now adding their voice to the calls. The chipmaker cannot afford to ignore them. Seventy percent of TSMC’s revenue last year came from U.S. chip developers such as Apple, Nvidia and Intel. By comparison, revenue from China fell to 11% in 2024 from, a peak of 20% in 2019, as Washington tightened restrictions on the country’s access to advanced tech. Jensen Huang, founder and CEO of Nvidia said his company, a leading TSMC client for AI chips, aims to increase supply chain agility. “If we add onshore manufacturing by the end of this year, we should be quite good,” Huang said. Nikkei Asia was the first to report that Nvidia is among the first clients of TSMC’s Arizona plant. “The geopolitical environment is very different right now,” Charles Shi, a semiconductor analyst with investment bank Needham, told Nikkei Asia. “Even if China taking over Taiwan is a low-probability event, which still looks to be the case today, it is a high-impact event if it happens. Therefore, for national security reasons, the U.S. probably is highly motivated to reshape the semiconductor supply chain, even if just a little bit.” A former TSMC executive told Nikkei Asia that expanding production in the U.S. is now “inevitable.” “Previously, many of TSMC’s clients worried that unpredictable natural disasters, from earthquakes to droughts, could disrupt chip production. However, TSMC proved its resilience and convinced them otherwise. But with rising tensions and risks involving China, this is a request TSMC can no longer avoid,” the former executive said. Trump, in touting TSMC’s decision as a major U.S. victory, said the U.S. would play a big part in the semiconductor industry should conflict break out in the Taiwan Strait. The U.S. has about 11% of the global market in advanced chip production as of 2025, and that is set to double to 22% by 2030, research company TrendForce analyst Joanne Chiao estimates, while Taiwan’s share would drop from 71% to 58% over the same period. Mark Li, a veteran semiconductor analyst with Bernstein Research, estimates the additional $100 billion in investment from TSMC could raise the U.S. self-sufficiency rate for advanced chip production to 40% to 50% between 2030 and 2032. “It will take time,” Li said. “But U.S. self-sufficiency will also rise for more advanced technologies, as TSMC gradually narrows the [tech] gap between Taiwan and the U.S. as the chipmaker brings more capacity for newer nodes to the U.S. over time.” U.S. production will also become significant for TSMC. In a bullish scenario, where U.S. wafers command a 30% price premium over those made in Taiwan, TSMC’s revenue from its Arizona plants could potentially reach 30% of the company’s total revenue by 2032. “We don’t see the tides turning overnight,” a longtime chip equipment executive told Nikkei Asia. “But in five to 10 years, if U.S. investments fully materialize, they will certainly weaken Taiwan’s role as the world’s top hub for advanced chips. You can’t expect TSMC to replicate these costly facilities in two places.” Eddie Han, research director at Isaiah Research, said establishing a major R&D center overseas to improve manufacturing brings the risk of indirect technology transfers, which could impact Taiwan’s semiconductor industry in the long term. “TSMC’s massive investments on advanced nodes in the U.S. would also magnetize the investment flows of Taiwanese chip ecosystem suppliers,” Han told Nikkei Asia. Lai Ming-Kuen, general manager of facility builder Acter, told Nikkei Asia that his company would consider participating in expanding the U.S. chip ecosystem, and added that shortages of sustainable electricity, water and land could be driving TSMC to invest abroad. “Electricity, in particular, remains a concern for Taiwan,” Lai said. Some market experts are slightly conservative about how quickly advanced chipmaking can be brought onshore in places beyond Asia and say capital spending does equate to output of viable semiconductors in the short run. Simon Woo, Asia Pacific technology research coordinator at BofA Global Research, said manufacturing yield and talent are two of the most important elements required to produce semiconductors outside of Asia. Yield is a key measure of production quality in chipmaking. “Starbucks coffee tastes the same everywhere, but semiconductor chip quality can vary market by market,” Woo told Nikkei Asia. “It’s like sashimi. … It tastes the best in Japan, and for a variety of reasons, but is very difficult to replicate in scale in other parts of the world.” TSMC’s plants in Arizona will become the chipmaker’s most important production hub outside of Taiwan. (Photo by Cheng Ting-Fang)  Woo said that all chip industry CEOs need to be mindful of the business risks and impact on profitability when investing billions in different geographies, as advanced chipmaking is extremely complex. Governments, too, need to take an extremely long-term view, and cannot expect immediate results in advanced chip production. In Taiwan, TSMC’s massive U.S. investment has become a political saga, prompting officials from President Lai to various ministers to repeatedly assure the public it will not harm Taiwan’s competitiveness. A recent Taiwanese Public Opinion Foundation survey revealed sharp divides: 43.8% are “happy” about TSMC’s additional $100 billion investment in the U.S., while 42.8% are “unhappy.” Over 60% believe it will boost U.S.-Taiwan ties, yet more than half still doubt the U.S. would defend Taiwan if China were to invade. TSMC declined to comment on the public opinion surveys. Konrad Young, professor at the National Taiwan University Graduate School of Advanced Technology, said Taiwan needs to moves beyond its silicon shield mindset and not tie the island’s strategic importance to just one company and one industry. “We should develop ‘multiple shields,’ so governments worldwide can see Taiwan’s other values,” said Young, a former TSMC R&D director and former senior advisor at Intel.. Looking forward, there are still many bottlenecks looming for TSMC as it builds more plants in the U.S. Finding enough dedicated and disciplined engineers similar to those in Taiwan, and overcoming cultural differences and language barriers in management, are just a few hurdles, according to another longtime chip industry executive who said things will not be all rosy for the company. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang. The AI chipmaker is just one of TSMC’s clients pushing for more diversified production. (Photo courtesy of TSMC) The supply chain is incomplete and costs are much higher. Several chip chemical and material industry executives told Nikkei Asia that they expect it will take a very long time for their investments in the U.S. to be profitable. “The [chemical] investment could only be reaching a break-even point once TSMC’s six plants in Arizona are all in production … That’s still a long way to go,” a chip chemical industry executive with knowledge of the matter told Nikkei Asia. Bill Chiu, chairman of Gudeng Precision, a TSMC and Intel supplier, said the work efficiency and cost-effectiveness of U.S. chip production remain far from ideal, making many suppliers hesitant to rapidly increase their investments in the country. An executive with a water, chemical, and gas handling equipment provider was equally reserved about the massive expansion push in Arizona. “We were shocked by TSMC’s announcement to build another five plants in the U.S.,” the executive said. “The costs are really beyond our imagination. Take the expense of welders for example. We ended up paying 10 times more in Arizona than in Taiwan.” Steel prices are also rising due to tariff uncertainties, another executive said, which could push overall costs even higher. TSMC said it is continuing to expand 3-nanometer chip production in Tainan, Taiwan. (Photo by Cheng Ting-Fang) Peter Hanbury, a partner specializing in manufacturing at Bain, said the $100 billion in additional investment would move the needle on U.S. chip production, but that success hinges on future demand. “Chip plants take years to build. It is important to consider the long-term need for the facility. In the end, customer demand will drive need,” he said. But from the U.S. point of view, Taiwan is running out of time to stick with the status quo as Beijing steps up its aggressiveness. Some in the defense community, including a 2021 Pentagon report, are warning that China could seize Taiwan as early as 2027. U.S. Stratcom Commander Air Force Gen. Anthony J. Cotton reiterated the 2027 warning at a conference in Washington last week. G. Dan Hutcheson, vice chair of TechInsights, said the U.S. is considering the possibility of Beijing taking over Taiwan. “Taiwan is the ‘Hope Diamond’ of technology and of geopolitics. Both the U.S. and China hope they can control it. TSMC is so critical to the world’s technology,” Hutcheson said. Ironically, while some in Taiwan worry that TSMC’s U.S. expansion will leave the island vulnerable, Hutcheson argues that the opposite may be the case. “If all the production is in Taiwan, it becomes really ripe for attack, because China is currently being held up by U.S. sanctions. If there is more production outside of Taiwan, and balanced with global production in the U.S., Japan and Germany, what that does is lower the risk [of a Beijing attack],” he said. “If you take money out of the bank, there is no reason to rob it.”

title: Cruise ships welcome: Japan to help upgrade ports
description: The government hopes to direct foreign visitors to areas difficult to reach by land. (Photo by Kosaku Mimura) Government to offer financial support to build immigration, other facilities HIROFUMI KANAOKA March 26, 2025 05:52 JST TOKYO — Japan will soon publish guidelines for ports aimed at accepting more cruise ships nationwide, with the government looking to boost the postpandemic recovery in calls and attract overseas visitors to rural areas hard to reach by land. Cruise ship calls at Japanese ports reached 2,479 in 2024 — about 85% of the pre-COVID-19 peak of 2,930 in 2018, according to the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism. Calls of vessels operated by overseas companies came to 1,923, reaching 96% of the prepandemic peak. Foreign visitors entering Japan on cruise ships numbered 1.44 million in 2024 — only around 60% of the pre-COVID peak. While the popularity of cruises around Japan for in-country tourists from Europe and the U.S. has risen, vessels coming from China have been sluggish because of that country’s economic slump, resulting in a gap in recovery between port calls and inbound passenger numbers. The industry is simultaneously trending toward smaller and larger vessels. Comparing port calls in 2014 and 2024, noticeable increases occurred in both small vessels with a capacity of fewer than 500 passengers and large ships with a capacity of more than 3,000. So in addition to setting up new ports of call, terminals that have already been accepting cruise ships need to expand their capacity. The ministry will create guidelines for port administrators nationwide as early as this March that specify the facilities and functions required to accept cruise ships. For example, waiting rooms will need to seat hundreds of people. For situations where a port that does not have a passenger terminal accepts a cruise ship, the guidelines will recommend setting up temporary structures and tents for shops and customs inspections. Recommendations will also be included on the number of immigration lanes required, depending on the number of passengers. Other guidelines will include installing roofing over pathways that passengers walk along after disembarking and the use of multilingual signs. The government will introduce examples of advanced ports in Japan and overseas, including Hamburg, Germany. The ministry will provide budgetary support to ports making changes recommended in the guidelines. Ports visited by foreign cruise ships reached 97 in 2024, up from 67 in 2019. New additions included the Okinawa prefecture island of Iheya and Sukumo, Kochi prefecture. Increasing the number of ports where cruise ships can call will also attract more visitors to areas difficult to reach by land. Ocean-going cruise passengers worldwide are expected to continue to increase and to reach 39.7 million in 2027 — up about 30% from 2019 — shows data from the Cruise Lines International Association. The number of beds on cruise ships will also continue to rise. Domestic operators are also growing. NYK Cruises, a unit of major maritime shipper Nippon Yusen, will launch its second active cruise ship, the Asuka III, in July. Tokyo Disney Resort operator Oriental Land will also enter the cruise ship business in fiscal 2028.

title: Asia will still need to make things in the future
description: Bangladeshis work at Snowtex garment factory in Dhamrai, near Dhaka. © AP Services alone will struggle to make up for further deindustrialization Priyanka Kishore March 26, 2025 05:05 JST Priyanka Kishore is the founder and principal economist at research company Asia Decoded in Singapore. The outlook for Asia has predictably dimmed in an environment of heightened trade uncertainty. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s latest forecasts show global growth slipping to 3.1% in 2025 from 3.3% in 2024. This is not good news for Asia’s export-oriented economies. The challenge, however, is not merely cyclical. The transformation of globalization and shifts in global trade corridors are heralding deeper structural changes in Asia, notably a faster deindustrialization of its developing economies. This poses a dilemma for a region that has long relied on manufacturing exports to drive convergence to high-income countries. To be sure, the trend of “premature deindustrialization” is not new. Similar to other developing regions, the relative importance of manufacturing in developing Asia, as measured by share of employment or output, or both, has peaked at a fraction of the income levels observed in today’s advanced countries. That said, the decline in manufacturing has not been rapid. Unlike Brazil, where manufacturing’s share of gross domestic product has plummeted from more than 30% in the 1980s to around 12% in the 2000s, developing Asia’s early industrializers — Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia — still have reasonably large manufacturing bases, accounting for 20% or more of domestic output over the past decade. But now, pressures are mounting. An influx of cheap Chinese imports is threatening to put local industries out of business and accelerate developing Asia’s deindustrialization. China’s low prices stem partly from Beijing’s subsidies for products like solar panels, and overproduction in sectors like electric vehicles and steel. Yet, neither detracts from the highly competitive production processes that underpin China’s edge in manufacturing and leave competitors struggling. In Thailand, more than 3,000 companies have shuttered their doors since 2021, as higher production costs, poor competitiveness and a flood of Chinese goods have made domestic production unviable in many sectors. The Thai steel industry, which has been a major casualty, has seen its capacity utilization rate drop to 28%, according to an industry association. Similar trends are evident elsewhere. From Indonesia’s textiles to India’s toy makers, the region is dealing with factory closures and job losses. The problem is only likely to get worse. Faced with increasing trade barriers in the West and a consumer demand slump at home, China is likely to direct more of its low-priced exports toward Asian neighbors. So, what should these countries do? Should they accept China’s comparative advantage in manufacturing and pivot to a services-led growth model, or double down on industrialization? The answer lies in between. There is a reason why manufacturing-led growth is considered the gold standard of development. Traditionally, manufacturing’s ability to absorb large numbers of unskilled workers from agriculture and deliver strong productivity gains through capital accumulation, technology advancements and economies of scale couldn’t be replicated by labor-intensive services. But this is changing. Thanks to the information and communications technologies (ICT) revolution and the rapid adoption of digital channels by consumers and businesses in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, services trade has expanded at a strong pace in recent years. Hence, services now mirror many of manufacturing’s characteristics. They are subject to greater competition, have the potential to scale and automate, and are capable of yielding higher productivity gains. A labourer works at a garment factory in Bangkok.   © Reuters Two caveats, however, are in order. First, low-end services that are well placed to absorb unskilled and low-skilled labor have low productivity levels. While they could benefit from technological enhancements, it is hard to envisage them delivering similar productivity gains as low value-added manufacturing given their limited ability to automate and scale. Second, high-skilled offshorable services, which embody the high productivity potential of services, require advanced skills that most of developing Asia’s workforce doesn’t yet have. Despite rapid internet penetration and improved access to basic digital infrastructure, developing Asia suffers from large gaps in advanced digital technologies like 5G and levels of digital literacy. Even in India, where the digital economy has experienced exponential growth, gains are limited to a tiny fraction of the population. Barely 1% of the labor force is directly employed by the highly productive ICT services sector. This limits services’ ability to be developing Asia’s growth engine for now. The region must first invest in advanced digital infrastructure, prioritize human capital development and strengthen and upgrade its skills base to make a productive transition to a services-led growth model. Given the substantial ground to cover and the rising importance of services in a fast-digitalizing world, this push should not be delayed. At the same time, policymakers should focus on measures to prevent a precipitous decline in manufacturing, while helping industries adapt to the new manufacturing landscape. The policy response should not be limited to industrial interventions, which are temporary fixes at best and risk creating inefficiencies in the absence of sunset clauses. A more sustainable solution is to address the root causes of manufacturing weakness, many of which overlap with the requirements for a strong services sector such as human capital accumulation and infrastructure investment. Without this dual approach, countries would run the risk of unemployed factory workers drifting back to farms or moving to gig work or other low-skilled services jobs, thereby leading to productivity and wage stagnation. Brazil’s experience serves as a reminder that an overreliance on services could stall convergence in developing countries without a well-trained workforce. Though protectionism, China’s manufacturing dominance and rising capital-intensity of manufacturing have reduced opportunities to grow through export-oriented industrialization, they haven’t completely vanished for developing Asian economies. The ongoing diversification of supply chains away from China and the emergence of new green and tech industries offer these countries windows to experience rapid manufacturing-led growth, even as they prepare to transition to a services model. They should not squander this chance.

title: Suntory president aims to quench Southeast Asia’s thirst for alcohol
description: Nobuhiro Torii, Suntory's new president, is a member of the founding family. (Photo by Kosuke Imamura) Torii seeks to repeat his success with soft drinks in Vietnam and Thailand SEI MATSUMOTO and YUIYA SHIBATA March 26, 2025 04:40 JST TOKYO — Japanese beverage maker Suntory Holdings turns its focus on the Southeast Asian alcohol market under a new president, part of the company’s efforts to reach 4 trillion yen ($26.7 billion) in groupwide global sales by 2030. Nobuhiro Torii, a member of the founding family, became president at the regular shareholders meeting on Tuesday. Torii will oversee overall management, both domestically and overseas. Former President Takeshi Niinami, now a chairman with representative authority, also will be involved in the overseas business. In an interview with Nikkei before the shareholders meeting, Torii said he wants to “place the axis of future growth in Asia, excluding China and India.” “I would like to look at the growth potential of alcoholic beverages, particularly in Southeast Asia,” he said, signaling plans to develop that region into a pillar of growth following Japan and the U.S. The company will begin a full expansion of its alcohol business in Vietnam and Thailand, where its focus has been on the production and sale of soft drinks and tea beverages. Suntory posted 3.41 trillion yen in revenue for 2024, up 4% from the previous year, with Japan and the Americas segments accounting for about 65% combined. Revenue in the Asia and Oceania category, including Thailand, Vietnam and Australia, accounted for around 20% at 617.39 billion yen. Most of this came from nonalcoholic beverages. Suntory’s new Australia plant will manufacture both soft drinks and alcoholic beverages. (Photo obtained by Nikkei) The alcoholic drinks market in the Asia-Pacific region is projected to grow 5% annually on average from 2024 to 2029, India’s Mordor Intelligence reports. Germany’s Roland Berger reported that alcohol consumption in the Asia-Pacific is expected to reach 102 billion liters in 2027, up 7% from 2024. “We need distilled spirits that are suited to the region, like shochu in Japan and baijiu in China,” Torii said. “Because it has a large population, if the market grows as it has for Japanese whisky and American bourbon, it could be a huge opportunity.” Torii plans to combine the expertise of Suntory Beverage & Food, which already has a foothold in Southeast Asia with soft drinks, and Suntory Global Spirits — formerly Beam Suntory, born of Suntory’s acquisition of U.S. bourbon maker Jim Beam for 1.6 trillion yen in 2014 — which has a long history in the overseas alcoholic beverage business. The aim is to approach everything from sourcing raw materials to production and product development from the perspectives of both subsidiaries. A factory that opened in Australia last year embodies this strategy. Suntory Beverage & Food invested 63 billion yen and began its first joint operation with Suntory Global Spirits, which produces chuhai canned cocktails and other drinks. The plant can produce both soft drinks and canned alcoholic drinks. Sales of canned alcoholic drinks produced there will begin in July. The facility also will serve as a storage and distribution base for whisky produced in Japan. By bringing the production of soft drinks handled by other plants under the same roof, Suntory boosts efficiency in terms of transportation and inventory management. “Once we can confirm demand and establish a supply system, we would like to expand the Australian model,” Torii said. The company hopes to produce both soft drinks and alcoholic beverages in Thailand and Vietnam. Torii is focused on Southeast Asia as he seeks to replicate his success in the beverage business in Thailand and Vietnam. He led Suntory Beverage & Food as president from 2011 to 2016, going to Southeast Asia to help cultivate demand there. Despite facing challenges, such as the decision to withdraw from the unprofitable Indonesian soft drink business in 2024, Torii’s experience in Southeast Asia deepened his confidence as an executive. “Even in a market we failed in, we could still have a chance if we change the way we do things,” he said, suggesting a possible return to Indonesia with alcoholic beverages. Sales for Suntory Global Spirits have more than doubled in 10 years. Overseas sales now account for over 50% of the total for Suntory Holdings, as its foothold in the North American market has solidified. Torii aims for sales of 4 trillion yen in 2030 but said he will not set a target for an increase in the overseas sales ratio. He aims to achieve growth both in Japan and overseas, including domestic alcoholic beverages, where he also serves as the top executive.

title: Japan back-end chip companies form alliance to upgrade supply chain
description: Amkor Technology Japan expanded production capacity at its plant in Kumamoto prefecture, Japan, by 50% in 2022. (Amkor Technology Japan) Over 20 companies to team up on manufacturing and materials YOSHINARU SAKABE March 26, 2025 02:48 JST FUKUOKA, Japan — More than 20 Japanese companies involved in back-end semiconductor manufacturing will join forces on production and material supply to strengthen domestic supply chains. The alliance of outsourced semiconductor assembly and test (OSAT) providers will hold an inaugural meeting on April 21 in Tokyo and Fukuoka city. Amkor Technology Japan and Aoi Electronics are among the companies taking part. The 20-plus companies expected to become full-fledged members represent 80% of the back-end chipmaking industry in Japan. The group will also recruit companies involved in chip tools and materials. Makoto Sumita, former chairman of electronics component supplier TDK, will chair the alliance. Sumita currently serves as outside director of camera maker Nikon, among other companies. Starting in the latter half of fiscal 2025, the grouping will work on creating infrastructure geared toward mutually supplementary production, as well as on mechanisms for joint procurement of materials. A database that includes the operating status of each company’s production facilities and other information will be created. Members are expected to conduct joint research with equipment manufacturers on labor-saving techniques for production lines. The group plans to collaborate with regional organizations that train back-end chipmaking professionals. Semiconductors are packaged onto substrates during back-end processes. (Photo by Shotaro Mori) Semiconductor manufacturing is largely divided into front-end processes, where circuits are etched onto wafers, and back-end processes, which involve assembly, packaging and testing. Back-end production processes are often handles overseas, mainly in Asia. Taiwanese company ASE Technology Holding is one of the top two leading OSAT providers in terms of sales, along with Amkor Technology Japan’s U.S. parent, Amkor Technology. Although Amkor Technology Japan and Aoi Electronics are major players in Japan, the OSAT sector here is mostly populated by smaller companies that originated as subcontractors for major chip companies. The alliance aims to solidify the underlying business environment to ensure steady supplies of legacy products used in a wide range of applications, such as automobiles and industrial equipment. The group also looks to partner with universities to develop next-generation back-end production technology.

title: Russia and Ukraine agree to ensure safe navigation in Black Sea, U.S. says
description: Ukraine's coast guard on patrol as a cargo ship passes by in the Black Sea in 2024. © Reuters Moscow wants Washington to 'order' Kyiv to follow deal March 26, 2025 01:55 JST WASHINGTON/MOSCOW/KYIV (Reuters) — The United States said on Tuesday it has reached separate agreements with Ukraine and Russia to ensure safe navigation in the Black Sea and to implement a ban on attacks by the two countries on each other’s energy facilities. The agreements, if implemented, would represent the clearest progress yet toward a wider ceasefire that Washington sees as a steppingstone toward peace talks to bring an end to Russia’s 3-year-old war in Ukraine. Russia, however, said it could not trust Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and it could therefore only sign a Black Sea deal if Washington issued an “order” to him to respect it. “We will need clear guarantees. And given the sad experience of agreements with just Kyiv, the guarantees can only be the result of an order from Washington to Zelenskyy and his team to do one thing and not the other,” Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said in televised comments. It was not immediately clear whether Moscow’s demand risked derailing the deal. Zelenskyy has previously said Russian President Vladimir Putin, who sent his army into Ukraine in February 2022, is not to be trusted over peace moves. Ukrainian Defense Minister Rustem Umerov said Kyiv had agreed to both a maritime ceasefire and a pause by Russia and Ukraine in attacks on each other’s energy infrastructure. But he said Kyiv would regard any movement of Russian military vessels outside the eastern part of the Black Sea as a violation and a threat. In this case Ukraine would have the full right to exercise self-defense, he said. Seeking to fulfill a pledge by President Donald Trump to end the war quickly, the U.S. originally proposed a full 30-day ceasefire — to which Ukraine agreed in principle on March 11 — as a step toward peace talks. But the Americans held separate talks in Saudi Arabia with Russia and Ukraine this week to discuss more limited ceasefires on energy and at sea, after Putin responded to the wider truce plan with a long list of conditions and questions. Trump is pressing both sides to bring a swift end to the war, something he promised to achieve when he ran for president last year. At the same time he is pursuing a rapid rapprochement with Moscow that both sides say could lead to lucrative business opportunities and cooperation across a wide range of areas, from minerals to sports and space exploration. Ukraine and its European allies fear Trump could strike a hasty deal with Putin that undermines their security and caves in to Russian demands, including for Kyiv to abandon its NATO ambitions and give up the entirety of four regions claimed by Russia as its own. Ukraine has rejected that as tantamount to surrender.

title: Trump reciprocal tariffs seen targeting Japan and EU among ‘dirty 15’
description: U.S. President Donald Trump plans to announce reciprocal tariffs on April 2, though the scope remains unclear. © Reuters U.S. to focus on trading partners with high barriers to avoid administrative overload RYOHEI YASOSHIMA March 26, 2025 01:17 JST WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s much-touted plan for reciprocal tariffs is likely to focus on a limited number of economies with nontariff barriers and large trade surpluses with the U.S., with Japan, the European Union, Canada and Mexico expected to be in the crosshairs. Trump had previously said that the levies to be announced April 2 would apply to all U.S. trading partners. But the president told reporters Monday that he “may give a lot of countries breaks.” Markets with which the U.S. has trade surpluses and does relatively little trade, such as African nations, could be spared. The reciprocal tariffs are expected to target markets that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has referred to as the “dirty 15” — a set of around 15% of trading partners that impose high tariffs and nontariff barriers, though the specific criteria remain unclear. A notice on a planned review of unfair trade practices by the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative named the EU, China, Canada, Mexico, India, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, among others, as economies of particular interest. Those economies are likely to be on the “dirty 15” list. According to the U.S. Commerce Department, Japan had a trade surplus of $68.5 billion with the U.S. in 2024 while South Korea had $66 billion and India $45.7 billion, all far smaller than China’s $295.4 billion.  Because these markets account for the bulk of U.S. trade in goods, even narrowing the reciprocal tariffs to just them would still raise the “large amounts of money” anticipated by Trump, the thinking goes. A more limited approach is being considered in part because the administrative burden of implementing reciprocal tariffs globally would be too great. The U.S. sets individual tariff rates on over 12,000 product categories, for each of the 166 members of the World Trade Organization, equating to roughly 2 million rates. With nontariff barriers also being taken into account for the reciprocal duties, it would be impossible to set new rates for every one of those, said Deborah Elms, head of trade policy at the Singapore-based Hinrich Foundation. Top officials at the USTR, which is responsible for implementing the tariffs, have only been appointed in March. It does not have a system in place to handle a complete overhaul.
